answer:
1. FRAME‐BY‐FRAME ANALYSIS  
• Frame 1: The signal for the driver’s direction is red. A “ONE WAY” sign with a left‐pointing arrow is clearly visible on the right‐side pole (near the Dunkin’ Donuts). This indicates the cross street runs from right to left.  
• Frames 2 & 3: The same one‐way sign and red traffic light remain in view; no additional signage permitting a right turn appears.  
• Frames 4 & 5: No changes to the intersection’s layout or signage; the right side of the intersection (where one might turn) is essentially the wrong‐way entry to a one‐way street.  

2. CONTEXTUAL REASONING  
Because the cross street is posted “ONE WAY” to the left, turning right into that street would mean driving upstream against traffic. There is no sign granting an exception (like a dedicated right‐turn arrow or “Right on Red” permission), nor does anything in the frames suggest a separate roadway on that side where a legal right turn might be made.  

3. MATCH TO ANSWER CHOICES  
• A (Yes) is ruled out, as there is nothing permitting a right turn and the one‐way arrangement forbids it.  
• B (No) aligns with the signage and standard rules: a right turn here would violate the one‐way.  
• C (Ambiguous) and D (None of the above) do not fit, since the signage is quite explicit.  

4. BEST ANSWER  
<answer>B</answer>
